page.title: 02TOPOGRAPHY : ACTON/LAVENHAM
page.content: The area is a low plateau with surface drainage towards the S.west. The bed- rock is chalk, some overlaid by boul- der clay. An area of glacial gravel occurs in the N.east; this is now con- cealed by Lavenham outskirts. A second area of gravel in the S.west was for- merly used for extraction of aggre- gates. One pit is now a landfill site and one used for preparing Ready-Mix concrete. Alluvial deposits lie along the Chad Brook. The landscape has a well-treed aspect owing to the exten- sive acreage of Lineage, Crabtree and Paradise Woods, some smaller stands of timber in remaining hedgerows. The traditional building materials are brick, flint, weatherboarding, lath and plaster with tiles for roofs. Steel cement and asbestos appear in farm buildings with corrugated iron roofs.
